title: 108_hr5375
content: The Act may be cited as the "United Nations Accountability Act of 2004". The United Nations Oil-for-Food program faced allegations of mismanagement, fraud, and corruption. Audits by the United Nations Office of Internal Oversight Services revealed mismanagement in contracts for independent inspection agents in Iraq. The audits concluded that the management of the contracts was inadequate and certain provisions were not followed. The United Nations Office of Internal Oversight Services found that the contractor in the Oil-for-Food program did not fulfill its contractual duties. The audit revealed inadequate management of the contract, failure to maintain staffing levels, overcharging, unprofessional conduct, and discrepancies in reported figures for goods. The United Nations Office of Iraq Programs was criticized for not managing contracts effectively. The OIOS found that the United Nations Office of Iraq Programs needed to improve contract management. The United Nations denied the US access to OIOS audits of the Oil-for-Food Program. The United Nations denied the US access to OIOS audits of the Oil-for-Food Program, undermining member states' ability to fulfill their responsibilities. SEC. 3. ACCOUNTABILITY AND TRANSPARENCY MEASURES FOR THE UNITED NATIONS. SEC. 3 urges the President to ensure OIOS audit reports are shared with member states promptly and without modification. SEC. 4 requires a report on financial disclosure rules for UN officials within 180 days. The curr_chunk defines key terms related to the Oil-for-food program and the Office of Internal Oversight Services established by the United Nations. The curr_chunk discusses the internal oversight responsibilities of the Secretary General, including monitoring program implementation and conducting management audits, reviews, and surveys. The term "appropriate congressional committees" is defined as specific committees in the House of Representatives and the Senate.
